H0.text: Kilowatts are the best way of expressing the amount of mechanical energy exerted by a force, as Theresa determined in her study of different forms of energy.

H1.text: Kilocalories is the best way of expressing the amount of mechanical energy exerted by a force, as Theresa studied different forms of energy.

H2.text: Newton‑meters is the best way of expressing the amount of mechanical energy exerted by a force, as Theresa studied different forms of energy.

H3.text: Foot‑pounds per second is the best unit for expressing the amount of mechanical energy exerted by a force, as Theresa studied different forms of energy.

A4.text: The joule is defined as the work required to produce one watt of power for one second, or one watt-second (W⋅s) (compare kilowatt-hour, which is 3.6 megajoules).

A5.text: The SI unit for torque is the newton‑metre, which works out algebraically to have the same dimensions as the joule, but they are not interchangeable.

A6.text: The SI unit of work is the joule (J), the same unit as for energy.

A7.text: Non‑SI units of work include the newton‑metre, erg, the foot‑pound, the foot‑poundal, the kilowatt hour, the litre‑atmosphere, and the horsepower‑hour.

A8.text: The foot‑pound force (symbol: ft⋅lbf,  ft⋅lbf, or ft⋅lb ) is a unit of work or energy in the engineering and gravitational systems in United States customary and imperial units of measure.

A9.text: 1 foot pound-force per second is equivalent to 1.355818 watts
